div.head: Votre Sang Est-Il Parfaitement Pur?
div.p: Une condition essentielle pour que l'organisme soit toujours en parfaite santé, c'est de tenir notre corps dans le plus grand état de propreté, non pas seulement a l'extérieur mais aussi interieurement.
Quand, en effet, le sang s'epaissit ou s'appauvrit, il en resulte de bien tristes maladies :

p.hi: Scrofule, Affections de la Peau, Anémie, &c.

div.p: Il faut donc nettoyer, purifier le sang et puis l'enrichir; pour cela, rien de meilleur que l'Emulsion Scott, faites-en usage et beintôt, comme les brumes matinales devant les rayones du soleil, se dissiperont tous les maux dont vous êtes affligés !
L'EMULSION SCOTT
PURIFIE; RÉGÉNÈRE; FORTIFIE.
En vente chez tous Pharmaciens et Droguistes.
Exigez toujours l'Emulsion avec cette marque : "le Pécheur", marque du procédé Scott !

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: Yesterday opened with a light breeze from the N.N.E. but towards noon the wind suddenly changed to the N.N.W. The day was rather warm, but becme beautifully cool in the evening. Barometer steady.

The Egyptian Gazette
An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880.
Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
MONDAY, AUGUST 6, 1906.
TRIPOLI, FRANCE. AND THE SULTAN

Tripoli is so near Egypt that any attempts ot the Sultan to increase his power there is of considerable interest to us. With regard to the question of the oasis of Djanet, whether the Turkish Government has despatched Captain Abdul Kader with forty men, the Porte declares that the territory is Turkish, being a portion of the vilayet of Tripoli, and that a holy flag is preserved at Djanet, whose inhabitants pay taxes to the Turkish authorities. The Frenoh Embassy at Constantinople presented a Note last week declaring that Djanet was recognised as French territory by the Anglo Frenoh agreement, and warning the Porte of the dangerous consequences of main taining troops there. To this Note, according to Renter's telegram of Saturday, the Porte has replied maintaining her olaim to Djanet as an integral portion of the vilayet of Tripoli Djanet is due west of Assouan.

The French have a great problem before them in their vast land-locked Empire in the centre of Africa. With remarkable energy and success they have gradually brought more of the provinces in their sphere of action under oontrol, but the vital question of how to utilize them after the conquest is one which most cause considerable anxiety for a long time to oome. Owing to difficulties of access they are likely to be as valuable as oolonies in the moon. Tripoli is still, and is likely to remain for some time, the best route to the new Frenoh empire. The greatest problem which France has to face

is the finding of means of communication and an outlet for possible trade. Sokoto, Bornu, and Bigirmi are in a fair way towards being settled, but Wadai remains to be oonqaerel. Whichever way they tarn Frenchmen are faced with thousands of miles ot semi desett, dotted only with occasional oases and almost impossible caravan routes through the belt ot the Great Sahara. For a century Tripoli haa been the best and most praotioal opening for trade with the oentre of Africa, for the methods of communicating through Algiers and Tania present apparently insurmountable difficulties. The oaravan routes from Tripoli are practicable, and with very little trouble oould be improved. The 'Parks have never attempted to exercise an active power in Central Africa, confining themselves within their most southern boundary of Fezzan ; bat geographically and through the complete monopoly of trading relations the Hinterlands of Tripoli, including Bornu, Bagirmi, and Wadai, certainly fall to the Sultan. These rights were, of course, ignored by both Great Britain and France when the Convention of 1899 was signified, and the protests of the Saltan of Tarkey went unheeded.

Furthermore, the scheme of capturing the trade of Central Africa and diverting it from the Tripoli route to Tunis has been another of France’s ambitions, for the oaravans pass temptingly close to the Tunisian frontier via Ghadames and Ghat on their way to Bornu and the Western Sadan. It is almost oertaio that a few years ago the Frenoh intended to take in Ghadames, which is a wealthy centre of Arab caravan traders and so tear the frontier as easily to be made a matter of dispute. For no reason which could be justified by the military necessity of paoitying Tunis, the French very quietly established a strong military base at the extreme south of Tonis in Gabes, this town being selected because it possesses excellent water, a rarity in this dry country. Large barracks and hospitals were built and vast stores collected, all being very nnostentatioasly brought with the troops by the regular steamers from Marseilles. No doubt whatever was felt in Tripoli about the intention of the French to seize some portion of it at least, and the Italians themselves were extremely nervous and anxious. They went to the length of picking a qaarrel with the Governor of Benghazi as though to look for oompeQsatiou in that direction.

Meanwhile the Sultan became seriously alarmed. With astonishing celerity he despatched steamer after steamer to Tripoli with men and stores, and it was compnted by the Consulat authorities there that in a very few months at least 30,000 Tarkish soldiers had been landed and for the most part immediately hurried off to the Tunisian frontier. ' New forts were bailt, the old ones were repaired, and the harbour of Tripoli was proteo’ed by torpedoes. For some months the Tarkish and Frenoh troops faoed each other at the frontier, and many little Rcidents occurred which could easily have been made the cause of a qaarrel; but the astute diplomacy of the then Governor-General, Rassim Pasha, warded off a corfiiet. For months the position was extremely strained. Measures were being taken in the town of Tripoli itself with a view to protecting the Christians against the rising anger of the Moslem population. But the Turkish position was too strong. The French coaid not master more than 10,COO troops to meet the 30,000 Tarks, who were by no means the andis-o plined horde the Frenoh had had to deal with under the Bey of Tunis. France was evidently not prepared or inolined to undertake an expedition on a large scale, and a joint commission was appointed to delimitate the frontiers, and the inoident ended. The oamp Gabes was deolared unhealthy, and the French troops were gradually withdrawn. Evidenoe of this abortive soheme ia still to be seen in the empty barraoks at Gabea. Bat the ambition to captare the trade with Central Africa still lingers, and many studies were made from Gabes with a view to diverting he trade from Tripoli. Oae of these schemes endei in the fatal termination of the career of the somewhat fanatical Marquis de Morbs, who, while attempting to penetrate into the inferior from Gabes, was murdered only a few days’ march inland by the tribe of the Chaamba. It is evident that the French wilkhe obliged to establish some means of oommnnioation with the Mediterranean coast if they are to benefit by their Central African colonies, through Beughaz: from Wadai and throngh Tanis, failing Tripoli, from Bornu and the Western SudaD. What there may be in the unpublished part of the Franco-Italian agreement, or what understanding may have been arrived at regarding the fature working of the caravan trade with Italy, we do not yet know ; in any case neither ooantry has an enviable task before it. And judging from the news in the telegram the Sultan has taken up a firm stand against all suoh pretensions.

div.head: Hashish Seizure.
div.p: On the 28th alt., the Coast Guards confiscated 183 kilos of hashish at Um el Kish, near bmailia.

div.head: Sudan Crops.
div.p: The crops are reported to be benefiting greatly by the rains which fell lately at Wad-Medani and Ehartoam.

div.head: Business Announcement.
div.p: Dr. Arbeely, surgeon dentist, has just returned to Cairo and is ready for business from today (Monday), 6th inst.

div.head: Brigandage.
div.p: The enquiry into the case of brigandage at Burn having been concluded, the trial will come before the local magistrate.

div.head: Pharmacy Regulations.
div.p: The '‘Journal Official” publishes a list of persons who have been condemned by the Tribunals for breach 36 of the Pharmacy Regulations.

div.head: Moulld at Belbels.
div.p: The Ministry of the Interior has given permission for the moulid of Sheikh Mohamed Alouan to be held at Eelbeis from the 2nd to 9tb inst

div.head: A strange Rumour.
div.p: It is rumoured that Mustapha Pasha Kamel has become a German subject. We have been unable, however, to obtain any confirmation of this news.

div.head: Khartoum Bridge.
div.p: The oonstruotion of Khartoum Bridge has been postponed indefinitely for financial reasons. This bridge is to join the two portions of the city.

div.head: Anglo-Belgian Co. of Egypt
div.p: The Committee of the London Stock Exchange has fixed Aug. 9 as a special settling day in Anglo Belgian Company of Egypt. Ltd.— 70,000 shares of £5 each, fully paid, Nos. 1 to 70,0C0.

div.head: Drowning Fatalities.
div.p: The body of the Frenchman who was drowned last week in the Nile eff Kasr-el-Nil has not yet been reooverel That of a native who perished at El Ramla has been found, and has since been buried.

div.head: less Majeete.
div.p: The policeman who tore up a copy of the "Egyptian Gazette” at Tantah station and assaulted Abd-el-Radi, the vendor of our newspaper there, has been sentenced by the Native Court at Tantah to a pay a fine and the costs of the case, the total amounting to £10.

div.head: The Brindisi Mail.
div.p: The landslip-disaster which for a time closed the Cenisio national highway and railway, has been remedied, and the Paris-Lyons Mediterranean Railway is again running through trains to Italy. Last week’s Brindisi mail, however, had to go via the Simplon route to London.

div.head: Alhambra Theatre.
div.p: This evening, Sig. Novelli’s oompany will present Brieux’s new 3-act comedy Gli Ava-riati (Les Avaries), which, according to the author’s description, is "a severe study of the consequences of the indiscretions of youth,” etc. The oomedy has met with considerable success in France.

div.head: Ban Stefano Casino.
div.p: The feat organised yesterday in aid of the Russian refugees in Egypt was an immense SUCCESS, the casino being thronged with people al1 day and the arrangements being carried out to the satisfaction of all. The winning numbers in the lottery were as follows : — 5,178 ; 10,204 ; 8,153; 8,985 ; 6,307 ; 877 ; 19,509. Boa Wood.

After a northerly wind the shores of Alexandria are strewn with masses of sea weed which, thrown up by the waves, form into hummooks along the beach, to the great annoyance of bathers and trippers. Could not this weed be removed, and made use of in much the same way as the Japanese do 1 asks a correspondent. Either as manure, or as stuffing for mattresses, the weed might be adapted to the service of rather than annoyance of a suffering community. In Japan the seaweed crop yields an annual revenue of £’00,000.

div.head: New Employment Registry.
div.p: The British Chamber of Commerce gives notice that it has commenced an employment register, which may be consulted by members requiring clerical or other assistance. Applications will be received, free of charge, from clerks and others wishing to obtain posts in Egypt. Address, Secretary, British Chamber of Commerce, Alexandria. [Advt.]
Instrumental Concerts
Every Night on the Verandah of the Windsor Hotel, Alexandria from 6 to 12 P.M. 5 O'clock Tea served on Verandah.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: Arrival at Kissingen
A Reuter’s telegram to-day states thatH.H. the Khedive has arrived at Kissingen, in Bavaria.

THE DENISHWAI AFFAIR. It is announced that three of the seven participants in the Denishwai outrage who disappeared were recently captured by the police, and that the authorities are in communication in regard to their trial. It is stated that in oonsequenoe of the prompt justice exeouted in the Denishwai case there is quite a movement among well-to-do natives to become subjects of foreign Powers!

FANATICAL OUTBREAK. A Santa correspondent writes that a demonstration against the Christians was made last week at the village of Sonnonres, Fayoum, by mobs of Moslems, who paraded the streets, brandishing nabouts, and with the cry of "Kill or convert” raided the Greek and Coptic shops, and maltreated the shopkeepers. The police intervened in time to check the development of the outbreak, and an enquiry is proceeding. This riot may probably have been due to the conversion of a sheikh to Coptic Christianity. "Al Mokattam” learns that a few days ago some low-class Moslems ot Akhmin, in Upper Egypt, attacked a Coptic funeral in that town and threw stones at the mourners. The aggressors were arrested by the markaz authorities, who have opened an inquiry into the oiroom-stances of the case.
The Egyptian Army

El Miralai R. C. R. Owen Bey, having completed his term of service with the Egyptian Army, has been struck off the strength. El Bimbaehi A. C. Jeff coat, D S.O., of the 10th Sudanese, has similarly been strnok off the strength of the Egyptian Army. His Highness the Khedive has been most graciously pleased to approve of the promotions of temporary Kaimakams S K. Flint Bey and C. McKay Bey,respectively assistant direotor of stores and assistant director of Cnstoms in the Sndan Government, to the full rank of Kaima-kam. El Bimbasbi F. W. Woodward, D.S 0., has been transferred from his service in the Upper Nile District to the 10th Sudanese Battalion. Lieutenant H. F. 0. Thwaites, Royal Engineers, who recently arrived in Egypt, has been taken on the strength of the Egyptian Army with the rank of Bimbashi. He is posted to the Department of Works. Leave of absence has been granted to the nndermentioned officials as follows :— El Miralai Mahmond Bey Tanfik, director of the Military School, nntil September 23 ; El Miralai Bond Bey, D.SO, director of steamers and boats, until October 9; El Kaimakam Cummins Bey, MB., Afsdical Corps, until 1 October 10; El Bimbashi Bethell, Artillery, until September 26 ; El Bimbaehi Wise, Camel Corps, nntil September ; El Bimbashi Rome, Cavalry, until September30; El Bimbashi Edgeworth, assistant direotor of works, until the 10th inst. BI Miralai Hawker Bey, Governor of the Red Sea province, resnmed his functions on the 1st inst. El Bimbashi Johnson, assistant director of stores, has been granted extension of leave until the 28th inst.

RECRUITING REGULATIONS. The following grievance has been brought to onr notice. It appears to be justified The regulations providing exemption from military service are very hard on the candidates attending the secondary schools. The regulations provide the exemption of the students attending Al Azhar even tor three years whereas a pnpil who ha3 completed his primary coarse of study in four years and joined the secondary schools does not enjoy the same privilege, although he ought to be similarly privileged.

UNION FONCIERE D’EGYPTE. This company has recently made some very pn fitable sales of land. 130 feddans at Dar el-Bakar were sold for L.E. 10,000, which were originally pnrehafed at a rata of L.E. 35 per feddan. The oompany has also lately purchased 400 feddans at L.E. 45 per feddaD, which are worth at least L.E. 60 in their present state.

THE SUCRERIES. The Railway Administration is drawing np a special tariff for the transport of goods belonging to the Socidtd des Sncreries et Raftinerie d’Egypte, as per the clauses of the contract of cession to the Administration of the railways owned by the company.
THE PLAGUE
Yesterday’s plague bulletin* records a fresh oase at Suez To-day, a fatal case is reported at Alexandria, the victim being a native boy living in the Labbane quarter.

div.head: EGYPTIAN PRESS
div.p: MR. FINDLAY'S CHARGES

The charges of brilery brought by Mr. Mansfield de C. Findlay in his telegram to Sir E. Grey against the section of the European and vernaoular press which did not hold the same views as the British Agency in regard to the Denishwai affair, are thus commented on by "Al Moayad” :— The British Diplomatic Agency appears to have gone into the Denishwai affair with definite political ends in view. One was to stop Parliament having any voice in Egyptian affairs, and the other was to suppress the liberty of the Egyptian press. What could the British Agency answer if it were asked to prove that the newspapers’ articles showed that they had received a large sum of money as a subsidy ? Has not the British Agency excited the Egyptian Press by the hue and cry it raised and by charging the whole country with fanaticism for whioh the Press is held responsible? How can the papers receive bribes for simply defending themselves ? Who is it who laid out this money? Possibly our contemporary, the "Egyptian Gazette,” would agree with us if we opine that the recent changes in the plans and policy of England in Egypt have baen due to the standpoint which the local Press took up in the Denishwai affair. These opinions of the Press were regarded by Mr. Findlay as severe strictures on the British Administration in Egypt. If on our contemporary refuses to accept this view, and Mr. Findlay remains unconvinced of the true facts as indicated by "Al Moayad,” then we, in our position as a national representative newspaper, will prove the falseness of the charge of the British Charge d’Affaires and will boldly declare that it anyone makes any insinuations of bribery against "Al Moayad’ let him proveit; otherwise, however high be his position, his insinuation mast be considered as a falsehood. "Al Lewa” remarks apropos of Mr. Findlay’s charges, that this is part of the English policy, to attempt to throw discredit on the native Press and thereby to remove the effects whicn the outcry these papers made over the Denishwai affair had in London.
NOTES FROM SUAKIN
HEAVY RAINS AND WASHOUTS

(From our Correspondent.) Suekin, Angast 1. Heavy rains have fallen on the Snakin-Atbara line snd wash-outs have taken place in several places. The line has been broken tince the 27th inst., and no trains are leaving jast now either ways, all traffic being stopped for the present. It is hoped the lines will be repaired to morrow. Bimbashi Lord, R.E., is superintending the wash-outs from Gebeit. The line was also interrupted for two days between Snakin and Port Sndan, but is in*working order again. The British steamer Wensleydale arrived from England on the 27th inst. with a special orgo for, the Sndan Railways, inolnding 110 steel bridges and cdlverts for the Port Sudan line., PURIFICATION OF ALEXNDRIA The crusade whioh Miralai Hopkinson Bey and the Alexandria City Police are waging against immorality in Alexandria is being seconded by the Consulates. The eleven women who were arrested is the city last week, on the charge of leading an indecorous life, have been summoned before their Consols, who warned them against going for walks in the neighbourhood of Mohamed Aly-rqnare in the evening. If they are again observed nootnrnally perambulating they will he sent home to their native lands. All the women undertook to comply with the wishes of the police. Two women, who are believed not be respectable, were arrested last night in company with a European man as they were piomenading in the streets, and despatched to the Italian Consulate.

CAIRO POLICE. With reference to a report published in thfl "Egyptian Gszette” of the 27th ultimo headed "Our Berbereen,” it appears that the facts of the case are as follows:— Policemen No. 1131, who was on beat duty at Clot Bey street, seeing a disturbance at Atfet E Suk, went to the spot to see what the matter was. He found an Italian named Giovanni Prola and a native coffee-shop keeper quarrelling, and a knife in the former’s hand. He called ghaffir No. 7, and both took the Italian and native to the oaraool, where a proefes verbal was drawn up against them for brawling. The chief points elioited by the evidence are:— (l) That the policeman was not present when the affair began (according to the Italian and his witnesses, they never saw him at all); (2) The Italian is not more than 40 years of age, and is not the proprietor of the land, whioh belongs to a Copt who looks alter it for his mother ; (3) There is no evidence of the ghaffir striking the Italian; (4) There were no Berbereen present, or at the most there was only one; (5) The "Frenchman” who interfered is known by sight, Oddly and is believed to have been a Qresk. The orderly r fiber who drew up the procks verbal made a note in same to the effeot that the European said to have been attacked was slightly drunk.

div.head: THE SOHAG TRAGEDY
How Mr. Horton Met His Death
div.p: Last Friday we published a telegram from a Sohag correspondent reporting the death of Mr. George Hortoh, an inspeotor of the Sleeping Car Company, whose head was cot off while the train on which he was travelling was passing under Kanafi Bridge. From itquirie9 whioh we have made, and from the inqnest whioh was held on Saturday morning at the German Hospital by Mr. A. D. Alban, we have elicited the facts connected with deceased’s terrible death, whioh are as follows :— On Thursday, Mr. Hortob left Lnxor by the 5.30 p.m. train in oharge of the sleeping and restaurant cars. There being but few passengers, the deceased, after dinner, went to the roof of the car, where he sat for some time by himself. It appears that he was aconstomed to travel in this way. Somewhat later he invited Gastave Frohman, maltre d'hotel, to join him on the roof, remarking that to travel in snob a position was most pleasant. Deceased was joined by Frohman, who sat on the top step of the ladder, the former being npon the roof of the sleeping car facing the engine. After remaining there some time Frohman oomplain-ed of the dost, which, he said, blinded him, and went back to the dining-car to get the dost out of his eyes. On returning to join deceased he found that he had changed from the sleeping to the dining oar q^d was sitting with his back to the engine. Mr. Hortob and Frohman then sat side by side, and on reaohing Kanafi Bridge the latter felt something strike his left ear. He bent his he id and Bext saw Mr. Hortob tumbling down head over heels. Frohman desoended to inform the conductor of the sleeping oar, and on arriving at 8ohag, whioh is only twj kilometres distant from the scene of the accident, they returned on a pilot engine and fonnd that the greater part of Hortob’s head was severed from his body, whioh was removed to the Sohag hospital, where the procks-verbal was drawn np. On the following day the body was removed to Cairo, where the inquest was held on Saturday at the German Hospital. The body was identified by Mr. Garriok, a fiiend of the deceased, and Mr. Chaker, chief controller of the company, and permission for bnrial was given, though the inquest was adjourned until Monday in order to take the evidence of Frohman. The body was interred the same morning. Mr. Hortob leaves a widow, who, we regret to say, will be left in very needy oiron instances on aoooont of the terrible death of her husband. We would, therefore, give prominence to the fact that the company are asking for donations in aid of Mrs. Hortob ander these distressing cironmstanoes. Both deceased and his widow are of English nationality, and we hope that the necessary support will be promptly forthcoming. Donations should be addressed to the Cairo office of the Sleeping Car Company, at the station.
THE SULTAN

AMERICAN OPINION. The ' New York Evening Mail” remarks :— Lately our ministry to Brazil was raised to the grade of an embassy, as a compliment to that oountry. We maintain an ambassador to Mexico for maoh the same reason. Partly this, and partly in order that our representative may not be outranked in either of those American countries by the diplomatic agent of any foreign power. But it is not as a oompliment that we have made onr minister to Turkey an ambassador. Of oonrse it pasres as a distinguished honour, but the motive is really qaite the reverse. Every six months or so the Ottoman Saltan has to he bullied about something. Force is the only international argument that he appreciates. Pressure has to be applied to him by the representative of tha oountry that has business with himj and it is most snooessfally applied by the agent who has the right to walk into the Saltan’s presence. Ambassadors porsess this right: ministers and envoys have the privilege only by the sovereign’s invitation or permission. Mr. Leishman, our representative at the Sublime Porte, is a good Snltan-balldozai, bat he has laboured under the disadvantage of being a mere minister. Congress has made him an ambassador. Now he will be a better ball-dizer than ever, for he can walk into the Saltan’s private office and say, "See here, yonr sublime and ineffable imperial majesty, it is up to yon to do thus and so.” Naturally the Saltan does not appreciate the honour done him in making our minister an ambassador. But if we oorreotly apprehend the character of Mr. Leishman, he will make an early call upon Abdul Hamid jast the same, and will gently but firmly convince him that no other course is open to him. When Uncle Sam decides to honour a Saltan somewhere, that Saltan may as well make up his mind to be honoured.

div.head: MUSTAPHA PASHA KAMEL
HIS VISIT TO LONDON
EXTRAORDINARY SECRETARY
div.p: A most strange secrecy appears to have been kept in regard to Mustapha Pasha Kamel’s lunch at the Carlton Hotel. The "Daily Express,” for instance, remarks : In the course of the four-and-twenty hours which ended at midnight yesterday, and at a hotel or other publio resort within a hundred miles of Charing Cross, there was held a meeting, conversation, or dinner, at whioh a number of gentlemen, most of whose names we are totally unable to give, met that eminent person Kamel Pasha. We regret being compelled to put this absorbing item of news before onr readers in such a form, as we are conscious that the report lacks precision, but such extraordinary precautions seem to have been taken to ensure secrecy that we cannot do otherwise. It is true an "official” report of the proceedings was issued —but then it is only an "official” report. As it happens, however, the secrecy of the proceedings does not render them less interesting, or, if we may say so, less significant. Yet we are puzzled to account for it. What possible reason can our Little Englander friends have for maintaining secrecy ? It cannot be that they are ashamed of their views, for, as we are aware, they glory in demonstrating to the world how often and how utterly their native country is in the wrong. We oan only suppose that, out of compliment to Kamel Pasha, it was arranged to give the proceedings as much of the air of a little conspiracy as possible. We do not imagine that dreadful things passed at the meeting. It is highly improbable that the guests circulated a oup of blood, after the manner libellonnly imputed to that pre-Canarian Canar, Catiline, and it is even questionable if the green flag was elevated above the Union Jaok amid thunderous cheers for Mahomet. What is more likely is that the missioner of New Egypt was bathed in a congenial atmosphere of "hot air,” and that, like the noble animal whose name he bears, the personage of the evening comported himself with much droll dignity. The Kamel of Nationalism has set out on a protracted journey. His ways may be devious, and his goal obscure, but his time cannot be considered to be wholly wasted if he succeeded yesterday in pawing some sand into the eyes ot a small section of the British public. Let ns hope that his futile efforts will give him his namesake’s proverbial "hump.” The following is the text of the speech of Mr. John M. Robertson, M. P. for Tyneside, of on the occasion of the historio lunoh :— Monsieur le Pacha, Parlant an nom de mes collkgues et oompa-triotes, je vou8 assure de I’intkrkt sympathiqne aveo leqnel nous avons entenda votre discoars. Nous cheichons avant tontk nous informer des conditions et des choses de votre pays et nons vonlons, pour cela, entendre les deux odtds. Nons e^pdrons qne vos copipatriotes parle-ront toujonrs franchemeut pour nous dire lenrs idkeset leurs plaintes.— Notre idkal est seule-ment de faire le bien de l’Egypte en oontrGiant tant que nous avoDS ViDflaence, Padministration gknkrale pendant qne nous sommes Ik. A notre avis, le contrdle anglais a beaaooup fait pour les finances kgyptiennes. Nous vonlons faire la mdme pour la vie sooiale, poor l’dducation, poor l’administration et poor la jastioe. H ne faut pas que FA ngleterre reste let pour etle meme. Qaant k l’affaire de Denchawai, vons savez bien aveo quelle inquietude on en a re$n les nouvelles ici. Snr cette question, nous ne poa-vons pins rien dire maintenant, tant que nous n’avons pas lu les rapports tffioiels. Maia je puis vons assurer de la sympatbie aotive et sincere d’ane grande partie da people anglais. Nous oomprenons bien vos aspirations et nous espdrons toujonrs qu’aveo prudence et deliberation, on verra un jonr s’accomplir l’ideal des Anglais et des Egyptiens : 'TIndk-pen dance garantie de l’Egypte.”

THE AGITATION IN EGYPT. The Parisian newspapers publish the following news :— "Le Journal Misr signale plusieurs incidents sarvenas daus la Haute-Egypte entre mnsnl-mans et chrktiens. A Sennourki, les musul-mans on fait nne demonstration dans les mes oontre les ohretiens qa’ils ont frappes et dont ils ont ravage les magasins. Les oonpahles arrotka ont ete relAohes. On oroit que la police, oomposke de musnlmans, fait oanse commune aveo les agitatenrs. De graves desordres sont en perspective.” A Cairo oonfrkre remarks : — La Loavelle ci dess ns indique qa’en Europe l’on exploite hahilement, en les exagerant, les bruits d’agitation et de complication qni ont en cours ic;. Nous avons dit et redit qne de tontes ces fanfares guerrikres il en fallait prendre et laisser: en prendre un pen et en kisser beanoonp. Cet dchantillon de reclame k rebours que Ton vient de lire, donne olairement a entendre que none sommes an ddbnt d’ane oampagre intdressde qni aura poor idsnltat, si Ton n’y prend garde, de ddgarnir tr£a sensihlement nos hotels, l’hiver ^rochain. * Si l’Egypte est si trouble, allons aillenrs,” diront nos visiteurs ordinaires. Et ce seront les antres villes de saison qai pro fi ter ont de l’aobaine. C’est ponrqnoi nous orions casse con a ceox qui oomplaisamment on sans le faire exprka tontlejen de la "ooncoirence.” Le fanatisnee ^gyptien n’estqu’un fanatisme de gargotte. On dpoavante les hirondelles d’hiver en faisant do bruit, afin de diriger leur vol Bur la Riviera on aillenrs. Tenons-nons bien.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: H. E. Faad Pasha, Minister of Jastice, is expected to arrive here tomorrow on his return from Europe.
Crookshank Pasha and family have left London for Vittel, in the Vosges district, for the asaal water onre.
Miralai Stanton Bey, Moudir of Khartoum, has returned from leave and has resumed his occupations.
The Porte has accorded the exequator to M. Charles Nicole, a Swiss subject, lately appointed Danish Consul in Egypt.

Mr. R. Draper, who has been appointed assistant controller of ports and lights at Port Sodan, has arrived in Cairo, and is staying at 8hepheard’s Hotel. He will leave for Port Sudan via Suez tomorrow.
It is said that Mohamed Bey Tewfik, Sub-Moudir of Ghizsh, will shortly he retired on pension.
Captain C. F. Wilkins, 6th (Inniskilling) Dragoons, and Captain S.G. Roe, 2nd Battalion Royal Inniskilling Fasiliers, have been granted leave of absence for two months.
Mr. J. H. Grieve, provisionally attached to the Sudan Irrigation Servioe, has been granted three months leave of absence, to date from July 1.
Mr. Schafer, managing director of the Shannon, Ltd., has arrived in Cairo, and is staying at the Continental Hotel.
Mr. W. F. Sarjeant, the popular assistant manager of the Khedivial Mail Line, returned to Alexandria from leave today by the Austrian steamer.

Mr. E H. Gandy, of Clifford’s Inn, London, who has been assistant to Mr. Robert Williams for the last two years in London, has just qualified for his diploma as an architect and A.R.I.B.A. at the Royal Institute of British Architects, and has now joined Mr. Williams as assistant in his growing practice in Egypt This is some compensation to Mr. Williams, who has just lost for a while one of the most apt and hard working of pupils in the person of his young friend, Mr. John Usse, who has had to leave for France for his military training.
Dr. Pris Orom, physioian of the 2nd olass in Port Said Hospital, has retired for reasons of health.
M. Othello Dilogo has been appointed chemist, of the 3rd class, in Kasr el-Aini Hospital.
The names of two Cairenes, M.M. E. Dombre and J. Gerard, are included in the list of commercial advisers published recently in the French "Journal Oflniel.”

div.head: DEGYPTIAN DELTA LAND AND INVESTMENT COMOANY. LTD.
div.p: The following is the report of the direotors to be presented to the shareholders at the ordinary general meeting to be held on Thurs day, 16th inst.:— Land Purchases.—At the close of the period ended 30th September, 1905, the area of lands purchased aggregate! 479,275 feddans, at a total cost of £127,950, in addition to a one sixth interest in valuable property in the Province of Qharbieh comprising 1,577 feddans. The principal properties are in the neighbourhood of Cairo, Tantah, Behra, and other important towns and villages. During the half-year under review, a farther 30,178 feddans of land have been purchased at a total oost of £4,320 12s. 3d. Also an interest in other properties, consisting of land, building, at a cost of £164,102 Ils. 3d. The total amount of purchases made by the company at 31st March 1906, was £305,990 9s. 7d., on which deferred payments amounting to £104,695 7. 7d. still had to be met. The whole of the purchases made are shown in the balance sheet at oost price plus interest on deferred payments. Development andSales.—The development of our properties has been steadily pushed forward and at the end of March, 1906, the first of the oompauy’s land sales was held, the results, after allowing for cost of drainage, roads, being in the opinion of the directors most satisfactory. As these sales were held at and after the dose of the half year, and only small amounts on deposit had at that date been received, the results do not appear in the accounts presented. Working Expenses.—The working expenses have been kept at the lowest possible minimum, pending results of sales of lands. The total, inoludiDg direotors’ fees, secretary, clerksge, and rent of offices—London and Egypt — amounts to only £887 8s. 8d. Revenue, derived from interest on oash deposits, rents and sales of crops, amount ed to £4,211 18s. 6d., which, after allowing for working and administrative expenses, left a balance of 3,324 9s. lOd. From this was deducted the loss as shewn at 30th September 1905, viz, £779 5s. Od., leaving a nett balance of £2,545 4s. lOi. to be carried forward. As ha9 before been stated, the proceeds of land sales, held at and since the end of March, have not been taken into consideration, but will appear in the next accounts issaed. General —The directors are satisfied that the land purchases whioh have been made are sound, and steps are being taken to re-open the sales of theproperty at the end of this year when the slack season in Egypt is over. These sale?, it is anticipated, will show considerable profits Vacancy on the Board,—The directors regret to have to record the loss by death of their oolleague Sir Elwin Palmer, K.C.B., K.C.M.G., one of the original directors of this company. Mr. J. W. Williamson has been appointed in his place. Directors.—Sir Auokland Colvin, K.C.S.I, and Baron J. de Menasce retire by rotation, and, being eligible, offer themselves for re-election. Auditors.—The proprietors will be asked to eleot auditors for the ensuing year. The firm of Messrs. Frank Davies, Meredith Co. having divided, the Directors recommend that Messrs. Meredith and Co., who are eligibe, and have offered themselves for eleotion, shall be appointed. The following is the profit and loss aocount from 80th September, 1905, to 31st Meroh 1906. Mar. 31,
